description.narrative: Business infrastructure development/Opening of Conakry as a travel destination: The Project will support the development of a high-standard hotel, which will help Guinea''s capital city address growing demand for quality hotel accommodation driven by increasing business travel and the emerging conference activities sector. Furthermore, the availability of a high-quality hotel is expected to become a driver for more travel (both business and conference) to Conakry in its own right, contributing to the development of the city into a regional center. Best practice transfer: The Project is expected to support transfer of best international business practices to Guinea, especially in such areas as (i) real estate development; (ii) hotel management; (iii) management of environmental, social life and fire safety issues; (iv) business ethics, transparency and integrity in dealing with employees, business partners, authorities and other stakeholders. Employment generation: The investment will create significant local direct employment of about 400 and indirect employment in the supply value chain. Linkages to the local economy: The Project hotel will seek to establish linkages with the local economy, specifically in such areas, as the supply of food products and the procurement of services (e.g. transportation). Encouragement of investment activity in Guinea/Demonstration effect: The Project will have a demonstration effect by encouraging other international and regional players to pursue investment opportunities in Guinea as this IDA post-conflict country works to improve the business climate, facilitate greater foreign direct investment inflows and diversify its economy from the natural resource-based sectors.

The proposed project comprises a greenfield development of a 280-room 5-star hotel in Conakry, Guinea (the Project). The Project is implemented by the Guinea-incorporated Palma Guinée S.A. (Palma Guinea). Fully owned by the Topaz Group of companies, Palma Guinea has been incorporated specifically to develop and own the Project hotel, which will be operated by Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide, Inc., under the Sheraton brand. The purpose of the Project is to reduce imbalance between supply and demand for quality hotel accommodations in Conakry. At present, Guineas capital has no 5-star hotels. This gap in the hospitality market has been hindering travel to Conakry and slowing down the citys development into an important national and regional business destination. The Project hotel is expected to help change this situation and to become an important part of Conakrys business infrastructure.
